Lyrics: Como Santa María tolleu un joíz aos dïáboos que o levavan e tornó-o a sa casa e disse-lle que se mẽefestasse, ca outro día avía de morrer.
Direct Translation: How Holy Mary took a judge from the devils who were carrying him away and returned him to his house and told him to confess, for he was to die the next day.

Lyrics: Como somos per conssello do démo perdudos,
Direct Translation: Just as we are lost by the devil's sway,
Poetic Translation: Just like we are by the Devil lost beyond retrieval,

Lyrics: assí somos pelo da Virgen tóst' acorrudos.
Direct Translation: so are we quickly saved by the Virgin.
Poetic Translation: That's the way that by the Virgin we are saved from evil.

Lyrics: Desto direi un miragre, onde gran façanna
Direct Translation: Concerning this, I shall tell a miracle
Poetic Translation: Listen to this tale and learn a lesson you can carry:

Lyrics: fillaredes, que a Virgen fezo en Espanna
Direct Translation: from which you will derive a great lesson
Poetic Translation: It's about a miracle performed by Holy Mary

Lyrics: dun óme que de dïabos ũa gran companna
Direct Translation: which the Virgin performed in Spain for a man whom a great band
Poetic Translation: For a man in Spain who fell into the hands of devils

Lyrics: levavan pera pẽaren con os descreúdos.
Direct Translation: of devils captured to put to torture with the disbelievers.
Poetic Translation: And was taken to be tortured in their godless revels.

Lyrics: Este sobrejoíz éra dũa vila bõa
Direct Translation: This man was the judge of appeals of a fine town
Poetic Translation: He held the position of a judge inside the city,

Lyrics: en que viçosa tiínna muito sa pessõa,
Direct Translation: in which he led a very agreeable life,
Poetic Translation: Where he had a lifestyle that was comfortable and pretty.

Lyrics: mui gran mannãa jantando e cẽand' a nõa,
Direct Translation: lunching at midmorning and supping in midafternoon.
Poetic Translation: Mornings were for lunches and the afternoons for dinners;

Lyrics: e grandes dões fillava, ca non dos mïúdos.
Direct Translation: He collected generous donations, not stingy ones.
Poetic Translation: Pockets were for filling with the coin of other sinners.

Lyrics: Este mui bon pan comía sempr' e bõos vinnos
Direct Translation: He always at good bread and drank good wines,
Poetic Translation: He enjoyed his bread and wine but didn't like to travel

Lyrics: bevía, mais non usava muit' andar caminnos
Direct Translation: but he was not much given to traveling the highways
Poetic Translation: On the highways to arrest the thieves and other rabble,

Lyrics: pera prender os ladrões; pero os mesquinnos
Direct Translation: to capture thieves. Rather he arrested
Poetic Translation: So instead, he'd just arrest the homeless and the starving,

Lyrics: prendía, e por el éran mui mal remeúdos.
Direct Translation: helpless derelicts and dealt harshly with them.
Poetic Translation: Taking from their withered hands the living they were carving.

Lyrics: El un di' assí estando que jantar quería
Direct Translation: One day as he was sitting ready to dine
Poetic Translation: One day as he sat alone, preparing for his dinner,

Lyrics: con outros que convidados ouv' en aquel día,
Direct Translation: with others he had invited that day,
Poetic Translation: Waiting for companions who were only slightly thinner,

Lyrics: oiu como de peleja ou de gran perfía
Direct Translation: he heard loud shouts and piercing screams
Poetic Translation: Screams and shouts he heard outside, so loud they were immoral,

Lyrics: grandes vózes e braados fórtes e agudos,
Direct Translation: as from a fight or quarrel,
Poetic Translation: Like there was a fistfight or a great and fearsome quarrel.

Lyrics: E dizend': "Aginn', aginna, mui tóste fillade
Direct Translation: saying: "Quick, quick, seize that man and take him
Poetic Translation: "Quickly," said the voices, "quickly seize this man and take him

Lyrics: aquel óme e da vila longe o levade."
Direct Translation: far away from the city."
Poetic Translation: From the city where he wastes his time. We want to break him!"

Lyrics: El, cuidando que peleja éra de verdade,
Direct Translation: The judge, thinking it was really a fight,
Poetic Translation: Thinking that he'd heard some rioters who thought to harm him,

Lyrics: mandou fillar a séus ómees lanças e escudos,
Direct Translation: ordered  his men to take up their lances and shields,
Poetic Translation: He commanded all his men to grab their shields and arm them.

Lyrics: E el saiu dos primeiros partí-la peleja,
Direct Translation: and he went forth among the first to break up the brawl,
Poetic Translation: And he went outside to put a stop to all the brawling,

Lyrics: dizendo: "Por Déus, varões, non seja, non seja!"
Direct Translation: saying: "In God's name, this must not be!"
Poetic Translation: Saying, "In God's name, this kind of fighting is appalling!"

Lyrics: Mas tan tóste de dïabos companna sobeja
Direct Translation: At once a large company of devils,
Poetic Translation: Suddenly a troop of demons grabbed him; they were chanting.

Lyrics: o fillaron, ũus negros e outros cornudos.
Direct Translation: some black and others with horns, snatched him.
Poetic Translation: Some were black as night, and some had horns, and some were ranting.

Lyrics: E mantenente da vila o poséron fóra
Direct Translation: They quickly took him outside of the town
Poetic Translation: Grabbing him, they took him out of town and held him over

Lyrics: sobr' un poço fond' e negro mais que ũa móra,
Direct Translation: and held him over a deep pit, blacker than a mulberry,
Poetic Translation: An enormous pit, mulberry black and green as clover,

Lyrics: e quisérono deitar en ele essa óra
Direct Translation: and tried to throw him into it then and there
Poetic Translation: And they tried to throw him in along with other victims

Lyrics: con outros, que pouc' avía éran i metudos.
Direct Translation: with others which they had recently put there.
Poetic Translation: Whom they'd captured recently according to their dictum.

Lyrics: E aquel poço fervía ben come caldeira,
Direct Translation: That pit boiled like a caldron,
Poetic Translation: Boiling like a cauldron were the slimy depths below him,

Lyrics: ond' el espantad' estava de maa maneira.
Direct Translation: which frightened him horribly.
Poetic Translation: And the judge was terrified; he knew that they would throw him.

Lyrics: En esto chegou a Virgen Santa verdadeira,
Direct Translation: At this moment, the Faithful Holy Virgin arrived,
Poetic Translation: Then the Holy Virgin entered, just as he was praying.

Lyrics: dizendo: "Leixad' est' óme, maos atrevudos."
Direct Translation: saying: "Take your insolent hands from this man."
Poetic Translation: Do not touch him with your filthy talons! she was saying.

Lyrics: Eles, quand' aquest' oíron, fugiron, aginna
Direct Translation: When they heard this, they fled hastily
Poetic Translation: When the devils heard these words, they fled in fear and madness,

Lyrics: e leixaron aquel óm' aa Santa Reínna,
Direct Translation: and left that man to the Holy Queen,
Poetic Translation: Leaving our poor judge to face the Holy Virgin's sadness.

Lyrics: que lle déu lógo consello ben qual conviínna,
Direct Translation: who gave him very useful advice,
Poetic Translation: But she spoke so gently and she did not let him languish,

Lyrics: ca os séus non quér ela que sejan cofondudos.
Direct Translation: for She does not wish Her faithful to come to grief.
Poetic Translation: For she does not wish to see her servants live in anguish.

Lyrics: Ca pero el de justiça mui pouca fezéra,
Direct Translation: Although he had done very little justice,
Poetic Translation: Even though this man had always taken justice lightly,

Lyrics: sempre en Santa María esperanç' ouvéra;
Direct Translation: he had always had hope in Holy Mary.
Poetic Translation: He had prayed to Holy Mary, clinging to her tightly.

Lyrics: e porende o livrou daquela coita féra,
Direct Translation: Therefore, She freed him from that terrible plight
Poetic Translation: That is why she freed him from the pit of vile aggression,

Lyrics: dizend': "Atán tóste sejan per ti connoçudos
Direct Translation: saying: "As soon as you acknowledge
Poetic Translation: Telling him to make amends and make a full confession.

Lyrics: Téus pecados, e filla deles gran pẽedença
Direct Translation: "your sins, do great penance for them,
Poetic Translation: Do your penance for your sins, she said; "admit them fully.

Lyrics: e en pagar o que deves mete ta femença,
Direct Translation: and turn your attention to settling your accounts.
Poetic Translation: Settle your accounts, be kind, and don't be such a bully.

Lyrics: e en méu Fill' e en mi ave ben ta creença
Direct Translation: Put your faith in my Son and me,
Poetic Translation: Put your faith in me and in my Son, and keep it steady.

Lyrics: e faz come os que están sempr' apercebudos.
Direct Translation: and do as those who are always prepared.
Poetic Translation: You could die at any moment, and you should be ready."

Lyrics: Ca sabe que mais dun día non será ta vida;
Direct Translation: "You must know that your life will be no longer than a day.
Poetic Translation: She continued speaking: "Go to work and cease to sorrow,

Lyrics: porên faz que, pois ta alma for de ti partida
Direct Translation: Therefore, when your soul leaves you,
Poetic Translation: For your soul will leave this earth, and you will die tomorrow.

Lyrics: que lógo sen estardança pera Déus sa ida
Direct Translation: make sure that it goes straight to God
Poetic Translation: Make sure that it goes directly to our Lord in heaven;

Lyrics: faça, e que os santos non lle sejan sannudos."
Direct Translation: and that the saints will not be angry with you."
Poetic Translation: Don't disgrace the saints above now that you've been forgiven."

Lyrics: Poi-l' aquesto diss' a Virgen, en un mui bél chão
Direct Translation: When the Virgin had said this, She left him
Poetic Translation: Saying this, the Virgin placed him in a lovely valley,

Lyrics: o leixou. E ele tornou-se lógo de mão
Direct Translation: in a beautiful meadow. He returned quickly
Poetic Translation: And from there he left without a dilly or a dally.

Lyrics: a sa casa, e envïou polo guardïão
Direct Translation: to his house and called for the superior and received confession
Poetic Translation: Reaching home, he went to church and, full of resolution,

Lyrics: e fillou del pẽedença dos érros sabudos;
Direct Translation: and absolution for his acknowledged sins.
Poetic Translation: He confessed his sinning and received God's absolution.

Lyrics: E null' óme mais coitado non foi queno visse.
Direct Translation: He evoked great pity from all who saw him.
Poetic Translation: All who saw him there confessing felt instinctive pity.

Lyrics: E outro día morreu como ll' a Virgen disse;
Direct Translation: The next day he died, as the Virgin said,
Poetic Translation: When he died the next day, there were tears throughout the city.

Lyrics: e u quis Déus que ll' a alma do córpo saísse,
Direct Translation: and when God chose that his soul should leave his body,
Poetic Translation: When his soul had left his body, angels came in glory,

Lyrics: os ángeos a levaron nóbres e temudos.
Direct Translation: the glorious angels carried it triumphantly away.
Poetic Translation: Taking him away in triumph, and here ends the story.
